Regional–Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (R-PATA)

Promoting Links and Improving Coordination Among 
the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS), the Brunei 
Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines East

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) supports three economic cooperation programs in 
Southeast  Asia  covering  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS),  the  Brunei  Darussalam–
Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area (BIMP-EAGA), and the Indonesia–
Malaysia–Thailand Growth Triangle (IMT-GT).1 This technical assistance (TA) project aims to 
promote links and improve coordination among these subregional programs and between them 
and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). This is important because ASEAN 
has launched wide-ranging regional economic integration initiatives under the ASEAN Economic 
Community (AEC) that have important ramifications for the medium- to long-term strategic goals 
of the three programs. Furthermore, the subregional programs can play an important role by 
testing new ideas and approaches to support ASEAN‟s efforts to realize the AEC by 2015. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
A.  Impediments to Subregional Programs Acting as ASEAN Economic Community 
Building Blocks 
 
2.  By 2015, it is envisaged that the AEC will be a single market and production base, with a 
free flow of goods, services, investment, skilled labor, and capital. This goal was translated into 
an AEC blueprint in 2007 with clear targets and timelines to expedite economic integration.3  In 
the light of the emerging challenges facing the region, there is a sense of urgency among policy 
makers in ASEAN countries to expedite regional integration to meet this tight deadline.  
 
3.  ASEAN‟s  “top-down”  process  is  struggling  to  meet  AEC  targets  and  timelines. 
Consequently, there is a need to take a new approach to expedite regional integration. In this 
regard, the “bottom-up” and market-driven process of the GMS, BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT can 
play an important role. However, in order to do so, these subregional programs have to address 
a number of impediments that stand in the way of their serving effectively as AEC building 
blocks.  
 
4.  The 2007 midterm review of the GMS Strategic Framework (2002–2012)4 found that 
good  progress  had  been  made  in  increasing  physical  connectivity  (especially  transport 
connectivity and power generation). However, less progress had been made in carrying out 
measures to enhance economic competitiveness. The 2008 Independent Evaluation Department 
(IED)  Regional  Cooperation  Assistance  Program  Evaluation  report  on  the  GMS  Program 
suggested that there is now a need to ensure physical and other forms of regional economic 
integration are complementary.5 
 
5.  The 2008 midterm review of the BIMP-EAGA Roadmap to Development (2006–2010)6 
found that project planning and implementation mechanisms were not in place and that the 
existing organizational structures within BIMP-EAGA were suited more for consultations than for

project  implementation.  The  review  recommended  an  assessment  of  existing  institutional 
mechanisms to strengthen project planning and implementation processes. 
 
6.  As with BIMP-EAGA, the midterm review of the IMT-GT Roadmap for Development 
(2006–2010) found a lack of progress in the implementation of its strategic road map because of 
a lack of institutional capacity. A business process review conducted as a parallel activity to the 
midterm review recommended a reorganization of the IMT-GT‟s institutional structure to increase 
the focus on project planning, formulation and implementation.   
 
7.  The lack of interface between ASEAN and these three subregional programs means 
there is a risk of an overlap or duplication of activities. For example, the Initiative for ASEAN 
Integration, which is the main ASEAN mechanism for narrowing the development gap, suffers 
from weak inter-agency coordination and monitoring mechanisms, resulting in duplication of 
capacity building programs and activities with those of BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT. 7 The Initiative 
for ASEAN Integration has been found to be an ineffective coordinating mechanism between 
ASEAN and the three subregional programs.  
 
B.  Impediments to Coordination among the Subregional Programs 
 
8.  One of the main reasons for the lack of efforts to coordinate and promote links among the 
subregional programs is that they are considered to be very different from each other, limiting 
the benefits from developing links among them. For instance, the GMS program covers its 
member countries in their entirety (except for the PRC), while BIMP-EAGA (except for Brunei 
Darussalam) and IMT-GT involve only some provinces and parts of the participating countries. 
However, although the GMS program is national in scope, many GMS initiatives, especially 
those on economic corridor development, are increasingly focused on specific areas of countries, 
requiring substantial involvement by local authorities. 8 
 
9.  BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT increasingly recognize that many of their initiatives cannot be 
carried out without the support of the central government. The national–local divide between the 
GMS and BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT (anchored in national development program priorities) is 
therefore converging as all three subregional programs have had to address the national–local 
issue in implementing their respective initiatives. 
 
10.  While  the  GMS  has  been  involved  in  project  development  and  sector  strategy 
development for many years, project momentum has only recently begun in BIMP-EAGA and 
IMT-GT.  This has made coordination among the subregional programs difficult. 
 
C.  Strategic Prioritization of Supporting Connectivity 
 
11.  ASEAN countries realize that to achieve the AEC goals by 2015, regional connectivity 
needs to be enhanced.   The Master Plan on ASEAN Connectivity (MPAC), which was launched 
at the ASEAN Summit in October 2010, is seen as a means to enhance regional connectivity 
and  buttress  the  AEC  Blueprint. 9 The  MPAC  featured  the  three  subregional  programs 
prominently  as  “building  blocks”  to  enhance  regional  connectivity  and  reflected  a  growing

8 A governors‟ forum was established in 2008 under the auspices of the GMS Economic Corridors Forum to 
strengthen cooperation between central and local authorities, and among provincial authorities along the GMS 
economic corridors.  BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT also have their own governors‟ forums.   
9  ASEAN Secretariat.2010.Master Plan on ASEAN Connectivity.Jakarta.

3 
convergence  between  ASEAN‟s  “top-down”  and  the  subregional  programs‟  “bottom-up” 
approaches to regional cooperation and integration.10 
 
12.  ADB's  many  years  of  experience  in  project  formulation,  appraisal,  monitoring  and 
implementation, especially in the GMS Program, would be valuable to ASEAN, especially in the 
implementation phase of the MPAC. This value of the GMS as an AEC building block has been 
enhanced  with  the  recent  endorsement  of  the  “program  of  actions”  in  transport  and  trade 
facilitation  (TTF).11 Furthermore,  in  BIMP-EAGA  and  IMT-GT  there  is  now  greater  project 
momentum  with  5-year  implementation  blueprints  being  prepared  in  2011  to  develop  a 
sustainable pipeline of infrastructure projects that will strengthen subregional connectivity. Until 
recently, the lack of infrastructure strategies and connectivity project momentum impeded BIMP-
EAGA and IMT-GT from being effective building blocks for the AEC.12  
 
13.  ADB‟s  successful  experience  in  enhancing  connectivity  in  the  GMS,  the  increasing 
prioritization of connectivity projects in BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT, and the prominence accorded 
to subregional programs in the MPAC all provide an opportunity for prioritizing the short-term 
development  of  connectivity-related  infrastructure  projects  with  high  impact.  To  sustain 
momentum over the medium term, a 3-year rolling pipeline of projects and technical assistance 
will need to be developed.  Over the longer term, institutional strengthening will be needed  to 
expand sustained project pipelines. In this regard, ADB could intensify its technical support to 
the ASEAN Secretariat in building the institutional capacity needed to implement connectivity 
projects and programs.13   
 
14.  The three subregional programs are at an important stage. The new GMS Strategic 
Framework (2012–2022) is currently being formulated. BIMP-EAGA and IMT-GT are about to 
begin formulating their implementation blueprints. For all three programs, enhancing connectivity 
will clearly be a core priority.  
 
D.  Strengthening Institutional Arrangements and Mechanisms 
 
15.  The three subregional programs have similar basic organizational structures to that of 
ASEAN. These consist of a leaders‟ summit, a ministerial meeting, a senior officials‟ meeting, 
working groups (“clusters” in BIMP-EAGA), a subregional secretariat, and a national secretariat 
in each participating country.14 ADB manages the GMS secretariat from its headquarters in 
Manila. The BIMP-EAGA secretariat is the BIMP-EAGA Facilitation Center in Kota Kinabalu, 
Malaysia, while the IMT-GT secretariat is the Center for IMT-GT Subregional Cooperation in 
Putrajaya,  Malaysia 15 –  both  of  these  secretariats  face  significant  challenges  in  project 
development and implementation and in resource mobilization. 16

subregion‟s central secretariat.

16.  While  ASEAN  cooperation  is  led  by  foreign  and  economic  ministries,  the  three 
subregional  programs  fall  under  the  jurisdictions  of  many  different  ministries  and  local 
governments.  This  has  created  many  institutional  processes  and  institutional  arrangements 
despite the fact that many of the participating countries are almost the same. There is a need to 
streamline and strengthen institutional mechanisms among the national government agencies to 
enable effective coordination between the three programs and ASEAN.  Within countries, there 
is a need to strengthen the institutional mechanisms between the central government agencies 
and local authorities. 
 
17.  In the light of the recent launch of the MPAC and the urgency of delivering the AEC 
targets by 2015, improving institutional coordination between and within countries will be crucial 
for investment programming, project development, and implementation.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome  
 
18.  The expected impact of the TA will be better coordination among the GMS, BIMP-EAGA 
and IMT-GT subregional programs and with ASEAN. The expected outcome will be an action 
plan agreed by the ASEAN secretariat, the three subregional secretariats, and government 
stakeholders to implement measures to promote links, improve coordination, and strengthen 
institutional capacity to implement the AEC Blueprint and the MPAC. 
   
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
19.  A study will examine the links and coordination among the GMS, BIMP-EAGA and IMT-
GT subregional programs and between the three subregional programs and ASEAN. This will be 
the  first  study  of  the  strategic  frameworks  and  blueprints  and  connectivity-related  sector 
strategies of the three subregional programs with the AEC Blueprint and the MPAC. It will focus 
on areas related to physical and institutional connectivity.17 
 
20.  The TA will have two main outputs:  
 
(i)  It will examine links and strategic coordination issues among the GMS, BIMP-EAGA 
and IMT-GT and between the three subregional programs and ASEAN. This will 
involve the mapping of subregional strategic frameworks and blueprints vis à vis the 
AEC Blueprint and the MPAC. Through a matrix summary, this mapping will identify 
areas in which the three subregional programs can help to deliver the targets and 
goals in the AEC Blueprint and the MPAC. As part of this strategic mapping exercise, 
physical  and  other  aspects  of  regional  connectivity  will  also  be  identified  for 
investment programming and project prioritization. 
(ii) It  will  analyze  the  institutional  arrangements  and  mechanisms  of  the  three 
subregional programs and ASEAN. It will examine possible ways of streamlining and 
strengthening institutional coordination between the ASEAN secretariat and the three 
subregional secretariats and among national agencies so they can cooperate in 
implementing  regional  connectivity  initiatives,  including  measures  to  support  the 
institutional capacity needed to implement the AEC Blueprint and MPAC. Measures 
                                                
17The physical connectivity component of the MPAC includes infrastructure transport and energy sectors. The 
institutional connectivity component of the MPAC covers areas such as TTF.

5 
to strengthen institutional coordination among central government agencies and local 
authorities in particular countries will also be examined.  
 
21.  National  consultation  meetings  will  be  conducted  by  the  TA  consultants  in  ASEAN 
member  countries  to  discuss  the  key  issues  and  impediments  to  improving  institutional 
coordination. It is also proposed that a regional workshop be convened to present the TA 
outputs, especially their recommendations on short- and medium-term measures to promote 
links  and  strengthen  coordination,  and  measures  to  strengthen  institutional  capacity.  The 
regional workshop will include officers from the ASEAN secretariat, the GMS secretariat, the 
BIMP-EAGA  Facilitation  Center,  the  Center  for  IMT-GT  Subregional  Cooperation,  and 
representatives from the national secretariats of ASEAN countries. The regional workshop will 
also discuss a preliminary draft action plan to implement recommended actions, including project 
prioritization (based on selected pilot areas that support the implementation of the MPAC).   
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
22.  The TA, estimated to cost $400,000, will be financed on a grant basis by the Government 
of Australia, and administered by ADB.  The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
ADB will ensure that the Australian Agency for International Development funding of the TA is 
made clear in public communications, meetings, workshops and other events funded by the 
project, and in other appropriate situations.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
23.  ADB will be the executing agency responsible for administering and implementing the TA. 
ADB  Southeast  Asia  Department‟s  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration  Group  will  be 
responsible for the day-to-day management of the TA and will coordinate closely with ADB 
Southeast Asia Department resident missions and sector divisions, ASEAN secretariat, the GMS 
secretariat, the BIMP-EAGA Facilitation Center, the Center for IMT-GT Subregional Cooperation, 
and government counterparts in the conduct of TA activities. The outline terms of reference of 
consultants are in Appendix 3. The TA will be implemented over a period of 10 months, from 
February 2011 to November 2011. 
 
24.  The TA will require a total of 10 person-months of international consulting services and 
10 person-months of national consulting services. Individual consultants will be engaged due to 
the diversity of tasks and specialized expertise needed to implement this TA successfully. The 
consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time).  Disbursement under the TA will be done in accordance 
with ADB‟s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).     
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
25.  The  President,  acting  under  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Government of Australia for Promoting Links and Improving Coordination 
Among  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS),  the  Brunei  Darussalam–Indonesia– 
Malaysia–Philippines  East  ASEAN  Growth  Area  (BIMP-EAGA),  the  Indonesia–Malaysia–
Thailand Growth Triangle (IMT-GT), and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of individual consultants under the supervision of the head, Southeast Asia 
Department‟s Regional Cooperation and Integration Group of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) will be engaged to provide technical and advisory services under the regional technical 
assistance (TA). A total of 10 person-months of international and 10 person-months of national 
consultants will be required. The indicative person-month requirements and terms of reference 
of the consultants are set out below.   
 
A.  Regional Cooperation Specialists (2 International consultants, 5 person-months each) 
 
2.  The consultants must be thoroughly familiar with the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations (ASEAN), Brunei Darussalam−Indonesia−Malaysia−Philippines East ASEAN Growth 
Area  (BIMP−EAGA),  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS),  and  Indonesia−Malaysia−Thailand 
Growth  Triangle  (IMT−GT)  programs,  especially  in  terms  of  institutional  structure  and 
mechanisms,  economic  cooperation  and  integration  programs.  The  consultants  must  have 
strong analytical skills with senior working experience in strategy development as well as a good 
understanding of the regional connectivity hardware and software issues and challenges. The 
responsibilities of the consultants will be as follows: 
 
(i)  Conduct  an  assessment  of  the  performance  and  progress  of  the  three 
subregional programs in achieving their respective vision and strategic priorities, 
based on the results of ongoing and completed sector technical assistance (TA) 
projects and loans, and evaluations of the programs within and outside ADB (e.g., 
studies and reports of other development agencies, government agencies, and 
public and private research institutes). This will include reviewing the Regional 
Cooperation  Assistance  Program  Evaluation  report  on  the  GMS  Program 
undertaken  by  ADB  Independent  Evaluation  Department  (IED)  in  2008  plus 
previous IED sector evaluation reports on the GMS.  
(ii)  Analyze  the  likely  contribution  of  the  three  subregional  programs to  ASEAN 
strategic objectives, such as the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) and the 
Master Plan on ASEAN Connectivity (MPAC). This would involve reviewing all 
relevant  strategic  documents,  including  sector  strategies  and  road  maps  for 
ASEAN and the three subregional programs.  
(iii)  Identify  initiatives  and  measures  that  can  contribute  to  the  strengthening  of 
coordination and development of links among the three subregional programs 
and  with  ASEAN,  including  activities  that  can  be  harmonized  or  jointly 
undertaken. 
(iv)  Develop a matrix summary that will map-out subregional strategic frameworks 
and  blueprints  and  connectivity-related  sector  strategies,  vis  à  vis  the  AEC 
Blueprint and the MPAC. This would include identifying pilot connectivity areas  
for  investment  programming  and  project  prioritization.  If  possible,  financing 
arrangements to support these priority projects should also be explored.  
(v)  Examine the key issues and constraints of existing institutional arrangements 
and the mechanisms of the three subregional programs and ASEAN to support 
the  AEC  and  the  MPAC.  This  includes  examining  in-country  institutional 
coordination issues and constraints among the central government agencies and 
local authorities.  
(vi)  Identify  possible  approaches  to  streamlining  and  strengthening  institutional 
coordination  between  the  ASEAN  secretariat  and  the  three  subregional 
secretariats (i.e. the GMS Secretariat, the BIMP-EAGA Facilitation Center, the

Appendix 3  11 
Center for IMT-GT Subregional Cooperation) and among national agencies to 
coordinate implementation of regional connectivity initiatives.   
(vii)  Recommend a set of measures to strengthen coordination and develop links 
among the three subregional programs and with ASEAN, indicating short-term 
objectives  (within  1  year)  and  medium-term  objectives  (within  4-5  years). 
Recommend measures to support institutional capacity building to implement the 
AEC Blueprint and the MPAC.   
(viii)  Draft an action plan that would include recommendations to support the AEC 
Blueprint and the MPAC. The action plan would include a selection of priority 
projects (identified in the pilot connectivity areas) that could be implemented in 
the short to medium term. 
(ix)  Conduct  national  consultation  meetings  in  ASEAN  countries  to  discuss  with 
national  secretariats  and  relevant  national  agencies  the  key  issues  and 
constraints on improving institutional coordination to deliver on key connectivity 
targets in the AEC Blueprint and the MPAC.  
(x)  Organize a regional workshop to receive feedback on the TA outputs and draft 
action plan. The workshop will include officers from the ASEAN secretariat, the 
GMS secretariat, the  BIMP-EAGA Facilitation Center,  the Center for IMT-GT 
Subregional Cooperation, and representatives from the national secretariats of 
ASEAN countries.  
(xi)  Conduct consultations with experts within and outside ADB. 
  
B.  Project Analyst (1 national consultant, 10 person-months) 
 
3.  The responsibilities of the project analyst will be as follows:  
 
(i)  Assist  the international consultants in conducting and coordinating their work 
under various components of the TA. 
(ii)  Collect and compile information and data to support the studies and analyses 
under the TA. 
(iii)  Assist  in  the  planning  of  national  consultation  meetings  and  the  regional 
workshop. 
(iv)  Assist in preparing relevant reports for dissemination or publication and carry out 
other tasks as required. 
(v)  Assist in the overall coordination of activities under the TA.
